text: hi everyone wreath and evutano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new
mogwai album as the love continues
this is the 10th full-length record from
legendary glasgow instrumental and
post-rock band mogwai
now north of 25 years as a group they
are effectively entering what is the
third act of their career
now if you're looking for an
introduction to the group's catalog
there's nothing quite as good as the
first leg mr beast
rock action commandai young happy songs
young team the band is often categorized
as one of those groups where
the first album is the best one but time
and time again mogwai have shown the
creativity on that lp
was no fluke as they have repeated
success
evolved their sound and forged a scene
for modern underground
instrumental rock but as mogwai pushed
past this point in their catalog
their output became a bit more hit or
miss granted i don't entirely hold the
shift in
style and quality against them because
by the 2010s in the eyes of many they
were a legendary band
who essentially started to coast on
their very
well-earned cred which allowed them to
put out some records that rest on their
laurels
put out some records that were a bit
more experimental for them that didn't
quite work
and put out a killer live album that
celebrated their back catalog with
special moves
not to mention their reputation as a
mostly instrumental rock band
made their sound pretty fitting for
soundtracks and scores which
they have done quite a few of those as
of late so now we have a new album a new
decade and i thought
maybe the band would take this chance to
possibly reframe but
after listening to this for the most
part i feel like we are pretty much
getting the same old mogwai
maybe now sounding a bit more ornate and
heavy
with massive string sections as well as
meditative electronics being a regular
part of their arsenal
nowadays they're also not exactly shy
about working in a vocal
every once in a while too the sound of
this lp if i had to put it in a nutshell
is really
the band taking everything they've
expanded on over the last decade and
incorporating it onto one album really
peppering it in
subtly here and there and the final
results are a mix of
exciting predictable and maybe a tad bit
overwrought too
the tracks on this thing that plot along
in typical mogwai
fashion but now with some additional
string sections get a pass but not much
else
pat stains or midnight if both of which
have some pretty respectable
and chaotic climaxes but it's the tracks
where the band really goes against the
grain that may be the most
disappointing like on here we hear we
here we go forever which features some
quirky beats
and some distorted fuzzed out auto-tuned
vocal leads which
i guess in concept are fine but in
execution the whole thing
sounds like a really bad bizarro kanye
west live set
or maybe if you took like daft punk's
human after all era but tried to execute
some so-so post-rock with it richie
sacramento is also a track that features
a lead vocal the singing
on this one is so drab it actually makes
the
instrumental underneath sound more
uninteresting than it actually is
so yeah i do have my complaints but
there are some respectable moments in
the first leg of this lp
like the dreamy and synth-laced dry
fantasy which is a
bit of a sonic oasis in the midst of
this project or
the steady and monolithic to the bin my
friend tonight we vacate earth
which is a very good first taste of this
record's dense
and colorful mix i love the way the band
effectively balances droning bass and
guitar as well as
buzzing organs stuttering synths on this
track
it's like listening to an instrumental
take on the velvet underground but with
a metallic slow core twist drive the
nail
lives up to its title pretty easily
thanks in part to
how pounding it sounds outside of that i
wouldn't say it offers much else though
because as soon as the band transitions
away from these heavier spots
they're just kind of playing with this
very basic loud soft
dynamic with these incredibly thinned
out
uh verse bits that really put you into a
lull
the record then improves on [ __ ] off
money where
yeah the midpoint does meander a little
bit but i still think the track has one
of the most gratifying climaxes on the
entire record not to mention it's
maybe the only song with a vocal of some
sort worked in that's actually enjoyable
ceiling granny is a genuine rocker with
a 90s flare
um i hate to make this comparison but
uh it's it's almost like if you mog
wi-fied a riff in a groove
from a nirvana and a 311 song and just
made it work oddly enough spiritualized
as well as lcd sound system felt like
uh very clear parallels on the track
supposedly
nightmares the driving trebley bass the
fuzzed out lead guitars those crisp
drums which of course contrast with
heavier sections that fill out in
pure mogwai fashion throw in some speedy
minimalist
synth arpeggios and this is easily one
of the most enjoyable and eclectic
tracks here then the closer feels like
classic mogwai in many ways
mid to slow pace larger than life sound
it's vivid it's overwhelming
it is a roaring beast and when the track
is at its heaviest the way these glossy
synth layers fit against the
wailing guitar leads the band is
throwing into the mix
it's just one of many examples of the
band's simple but effective approach to
sound play
but with all of that being said while i
did like this record slightly on the
whole
there were definitely tracks that in my
opinion did not work at all
there were tracks that to me didn't
really
exceed expectations in any way shape or
form
really mog why by the books but with
maybe a
a bit of electronic or i guess
orchestral window dressing
while it's not their worst i just think
this record is another okay release from
the band
and that's about it
you know feeling a light six
